metadata.case_name: Sardul Singh Caveeshar & Ors. v. State

facts.text: Four appellants along with Ramniklal Keshavlal Jhaveri (acquitted) committed for trial on charges of conspiracy to commit criminal breach of trust of funds of Jupiter General Insurance Co. Ltd. and commission thereof as directors and agents.

Appellants convicted by jury (majority for Caveeshar and Kaul, unanimous for Mehta and Guha); Sessions Judge accepted verdicts and sentenced: Caveeshar RI 3 years + fine Rs.2500; Kaul RI 5 years + fine Rs.5000; Mehta RI 5 years + fine Rs.5000; Guha RI 3 years + fine Rs.2500.
Bombay High Court upheld convictions in Criminal Appeals Nos. 861-864 of 1956 on 1956-11-21.
Conspiracy period: December 1, 1948 to January 31, 1949, involving eight persons including Lala Shankarlal (died), Doshi (died), Mahajan (trial separated).
Lala Shankarlal: Managing director of Tropical Insurance Co. Ltd., director Punjab Central Bank, controlling Delhi Swadesi Co-operative Stores, Forward Bloc leader.
Kaul (A1): Barrister in Delhi December 1948.
Mehta (A2): Manager Bombay Office (General) of Tropical.
Jhaveri (A3, acquitted): Bombay solicitor.
Guha (A4): Accountant of Tropical December 1948.
Caveeshar (A5): Managing director Peoples Insurance Co. and New Hindustan Bank, Forward Bloc member.

Prosecution case: Lala Shankarlal planned to acquire controlling block of Jupiter shares (about 63,000 shares owned by Bajaj and Khaitan via New Prahlad Mills) using Jupiter's own funds, as Tropical was tottering financially.
Jupiter had investments face value Rs. two crores, 1,24,966 ordinary shares Rs.100 each (Rs.15 called up), cumulative preference shares.

Negotiations via Mayadas/Chopra then Naurangrai; bargain at Rs.53/share total Rs.33,39,000; Rs.5,39,000 cash direct to Bajaj/Khaitan, Rs.28 lakhs shown price, balance by Jan 20, 1949 or Rs.5 lakhs damages.
Rs.4,85,000 paid to Bajaj Dec 29, 1948; formal agreement Dec 29, 1948.

Dec 29, 1948 board meeting: allotted 1,250 qualifying shares to Lala Shankarlal, Kaul, Mehta, Jhaveri, Doshi (250 each); confirmed transfers; old directors resigned; Lala Shankarlal appointed MD; Khaitan resigned MD.

Jan 11, 1949 new directors meeting: sell securities Rs.15 lakhs, overdraft Rs.14 lakhs Punjab National Bank on govt securities; loan Rs.25,15,000 to Caveeshar on equitable mortgage Delhi properties (app Jan 4, valuation report); purchase Delhi Stores plots Rs.2,60,000.

Securities taken personal custody Mehta; sold Rs.15 lakhs face value realising Rs.13,99,768; overdraft Rs.14,21,812 on Rs.15 lakhs securities; total Rs.28,21,580; Rs.28,15,000 to Bank of India credited New Prahlad Mills cash-credit.
Negotiations details: Mayadas authority letter Dec 15, 1948; Naurangrai pro-note Rs.5,39,000 Dec 23; payments via cheques; Rs.4,85,000 to Bajaj Ghaziabad; agreement Ex.Z-171.
Jan 4, 1949 meeting: Kaul director-in-charge; sub-committees; POA to Lala Shankarlal; Kaul/Mehta bank operations; policyholder directors/general manager Joel resigned.
Jan 11 resolutions: withdraw Joel letter Ex.Z-30; close safe custody Bank of India Ex.Z-32; disputed res 7/8 sale/overdraft.
Securities sale authorised brokers Ex.Z-36 Jan 13; proceeds credited banks Jan 17; Lala Shankarlal overdraft Delhi Rs.14 lakhs Jan 17 draft to Bombay Jan 18.
Jan 19 Mehta letters: pay Rs.28,15,000 Punjab NB to Bank of India for shares; cheque Rs.75,000 Tropical to Jupiter.
Five cheques Jupiter to Tropical total Rs.27,65,700 Jan 18-20 (Delhi Stores Rs.2,55,050 endorsed; others or order/bearer); deposited Jan 20 pay-in-slip Guha; then Rs.28,15,000 paid for 61,394 shares.
Jan 20 meeting: confirmed Jan 11 minutes; res confirming Caveeshar loan Rs.25,10,650, Delhi Stores Rs.2,55,050, securities sale/pledge.

Jan 22 Tropical board: confirmed Jupiter shares purchase Rs.28,15,000; 48,399 to Delhi Stores; sale head office/building/plots to Caveeshar Rs.23,50,000+6,50,000 Dec 23; Chandni Chowk to Delhi Stores Rs.2,60,000.

Prosecution evidence: missing entries/papers; ex-employees Subramaniam/Rege; shareholder notices/suit Jan 19, 1949; financial position Tropical/Delhi Stores/Caveeshar poor; no Caveeshar properties; Delhi Stores defunct.

Second period Feb-Dec 1949: Manipulations to close Jan transactions: May 25 meeting Caveeshar repaying, invest Rs.14 lakhs Tropical shares (later 54,000); four transactions totalling Rs.25,10,650 repayment shown: Raghavji Rs.4L, fresh Caveeshar Rs.5.3L, Misri Devi Rs.1L, Tropical shares Rs.14L, balance transfer.
Raghavji loan Nov 5 Rs.5L equitable mortgage Cutch properties; disbursed Rs.3L cash Jupiter + Rs.2L book from Caveeshar; reduced Caveeshar loan Rs.4L.
Fresh Caveeshar loan Nov 5 Rs.5.3L pledge Peoples Insurance shares.
Misri Devi loan Dec 20 Rs.5L Delhi property; funds sent Delhi; reduced Caveeshar Rs.1L.
Tropical shares purchase confirmed Dec 20 Rs.14L; book adjustment via Caveeshar.
Delhi Stores plots: Tropical sold Chandni Chowk to Delhi Stores Rs.2,60,000.
Other 1949: Rege notice May 13 fraud allegation, misfeasance Aug 10 withdrawn Sep 15; brokerage disputes; ante-dated docs; letters Kaul/Guha/Caveeshar.
Third period 1950: Auditors queried Caveeshar loan Jan 6/Feb 6; no docs; threatened report Superintendent Insurance; evasion till Jul 24 draft report.

Repayments shown 1950: Fresh Caveeshar Rs.5.3L via Tropical securities sale Sep (Jupiter secs substituted Grindlays); Raghavji Rs.5.18L cash Oct 27; Misri Devi Rs.5L+int Oct via circular funds; Tropical shares Rs.14L via Empire India Rs.15L cheque Oct 26 shown sale proceeds.
Empire India control acquired Oct 1950: Rs.43L+ paid via Damodar Swarup Seth cheques funded by Jupiter securities Rs.48.75L withdrawn to his cash-credit PNB; used to buy control from Ramratan Gupta.
Empire funds Rs.20L advance Oct 26/27 to Jupiter disguised as securities sale; used for Tropical shares/Raghavji adjustments; auditors satisfied Oct 29; AGM Oct 23.
Shares distribution: Qualifying 1250; later to Delhi Stores/Tropical then to accused/employees/nominees; no payment by transferees.

legal_issues.text: Admissibility of evidence relating to events in 1950 (outside conspiracy period Dec 1, 1948-Jan 31, 1949) under s.10 Evidence Act and other sections (ss.6,8,9,11,14).
Whether 1950 evidence admissible to prove bogus nature of Jan 1949 transactions and criminal intent of individual accused.

petitioner_arguments.text: Evidence of 1950 transactions inadmissible under s.10 Evidence Act as outside conspiracy period; only acts during Dec 1948-Jan 1949 admissible against co-conspirators; 1950 events screen 1949 transactions, not original conspiracy; voluminous evidence confused/prejudiced jury.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.10 Indian Evidence Act; Mirza Akbar v. The King-Emperor

petitioner_arguments.text: Subsequent conduct of conspirator (esp. deceased Lala Shankarlal) inadmissible against others for proving conspiracy or participation.
Each accused innocent tool of Lala Shankarlal.

respondent_arguments.text: 1950 evidence admissible under ss.6,8,9,11,14 Evidence Act to prove bogus character of original Jan 1949 transactions (Caveeshar loan/Delhi Stores) and criminal intent of each accused.
1950 transactions integrally connected to screen Jan 1949 bogus deals due to auditors' scrutiny.

court_reasoning.text: s.10 Evidence Act limited to acts during conspiracy period carrying out common intention; 1949 screening acts conceded admissible; 1950 acts admissible as relevant to bogus nature of Jan 1949 transactions (essential issue) and individual criminal intent (rebut likely innocent participation defense).
court_reasoning.key_observation: 1950 evidence links to dispel suspicion on original transactions; admissible under other Evidence Act sections despite wide wording needing limits.

court_reasoning.text: Trial judge distinguished: subsequent conduct admissible against actor only, not others for conspiracy proof; charge cautioned jury; no proven prejudice (Jhaveri acquitted); inherent risk in joint trials.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Evidence used for bogus character, not directly for conspiracy proof.

holdings.text: Evidence of 1950 transactions admissible to prove bogus character of Jan 1949 transactions and individual criminal intent; not inadmissible under s.10 as outside period but relevant under ss.6,8,9,11,14.
No prejudice shown to vitiate convictions despite volume/complexity.

precedents_cited.relevance: Limits s.10 Evidence Act to acts in carrying out conspiracy during specified period.
Sections like s.11 need limited construction.
Inherent prejudice risk in joint trials with partially inadmissible evidence; caution needed but not vitiating absent serious prejudice.

precedents_cited.case_name: Makin v. The Attorney-General for New South Wales
precedents_cited.relevance: Prosecution may lead rebuttal evidence of likely defense on intention as part of case.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Admissibility of acts/statements outside conspiracy period in conspiracy cases; relevance to bogus transactions and intent.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court considered admissibility arguments in appeals by special leave against High Court upholding Sessions convictions; held 1950 evidence admissible, no prejudice vitiating trial (text truncated before final disposition).

key_quotes.text: "s. 10 of the Evidence Act must be construed in accordance with the principle that the thing done, written, or spoken, was something done in carrying out the conspiracy and was receivable as a step in the proof of the conspiracy."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines limits of s.10 Evidence Act from Mirza Akbar.

key_quotes.text: "the statements and actions of any one of the persons mentioned in the charge are not admissible beyond the period of conspiracy unless they are authorised by any of the accused persons"
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
key_quotes.significance: Trial judge's ruling on admissibility (interlocutory judgment No.6).

key_quotes.text: "We consider the above transactions mostly unconscionable and we fail to understand how any responsible management could sell Government securities and invest the proceeds in a huge lot of shares in Tropical Insurance Co. Ltd."
key_quotes.speaker: prosecution
key_quotes.significance: Auditors' letter Feb 6, 1950 highlighting suspicious transactions.
